abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Polymorphisms in the interleukin-10 (<jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic>) gene have been linked to the severity of the patients infected with the viral infections. This study aimed to assess if the <jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic> gene polymorphisms rs1800871, rs1800872, and rs1800896 were linked to coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19) mortality in different severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) variants in the Iranian population.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>For genotyping <jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic> rs1800871, rs1800872, and rs1800896, this study used the polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism method in 1,734 recovered and 1,450 deceased patients.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The obtained finding indicated <jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic> rs1800871 CC genotype in the Alpha variant and CT genotype in the Delta variant had a relationship with COVID-19 mortality; however, there was no association between rs1800871 polymorphism and the Omicron BA.5 variant. The COVID-19 mortality rate was associated with <jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic> rs1800872 TT genotype in the Alpha and Omicron BA.5 variants and GT in the Alpha and Delta variants. The COVID-19 mortality rate was associated with <jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic> rs1800896 GG and AG genotypes in the Delta and Omicron BA.5; nevertheless, there was no association between rs1800896 polymorphism with the Alpha variant. According to the obtained data, the GTA haplotype was the most common of haplotype in different SARS-CoV-2 variants. The TCG haplotype was related to COVID-19 mortality in the Alpha, Delta and Omicron BA.5 variants.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The <jats:italic>IL10</jats:italic> polymorphisms had an impact on COVID-19 infection, and these polymorphisms had different effects in various SARS-CoV-2 variants. To verify the obtained results, further studies should be conducted on various ethnic groups.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The Ethics Committee of Ilam University of Medical Sciences granted approval for this study (IR.MEDILAM.REC.I400.237). The Declaration of Helsinki was followed when conducting the study. Moreover, written informed consent was directly obtained from all participants.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
